answers.answer: That is probably just his professional opinion regarding the number of stents allowed in an artery.  I don't think that there's any particular number that is set in stone.I'd say it's real hard to argue with success.

I have 5 stents in my LAD as well, so I hope your doc is wrong.  My doc (who is a very good cardio) seems to think I'm okay.  I have been told that if I have any more blockages in my LAD, I will have to have a bypass but so far I've stayed clean/open!  I always tell my docs up front not to do anything that could prevent a bypass down the road, so I'm confident that right now my 5 stents don't prevent it.  Hope you get a good answer to your concerns!

I hope he is wrong, too.  I have three in the LAD and five in the RCA.  I also ask the doc to please leave room for bypass, and I'm assured that they have it mapped out for that eventuality.  It has been explained to me that because I'm in pretty good physical condition for someone close to 70, and because I have   CAD in only two vessels they would like to 'save' my veins as long as they can.  Right now I'm chugging along at a good clip, exercising daily and feeling great, so I'm a big fan of multiple stents for now.  Eventually I know I'll have bypass but I'd like to delay it as long as I can.Best wishes.

My wife has a total of 15 between her RCA and LCX.  She's fine and you will be too.  Just keep exercising, following a low fat diet, take your meds and keep your arteries clean.  You didn't say if the dr was an interventional cardioogist or a regular cardiologist.  A regular cardiologist would always say too many stents because that is not their job.  An interventional guy who is skittish and who automatically reciommends having your chest cracked open is a guy you don't want.  Bypass is not an easy thing to recover from - no matte what anyone tells you.Keep up the good work!

My cardio doc is a non-interventional (meds only but there are exceptions) and if medication can dilate the vessels and prevent angina there is no medical justification for intervention (bypass/stents) that interrupts the important function of the endothelium cells.A stent interrupts the thin lining (endothelium cells) of the arteries, and these cells are sensitive to blood velocity and signal the neuro system to regulate the cardio/vascular biological functionality.  That includes vasodilation, and hence the control of blood pressure, blood clotting (thrombosis & fibrinolysis), atherosclerosis, formation of new blood vessels (angiogenesis), inflammation and swelling (edema).Endothelium-derived relaxing factor was originally the name given to several proposed factors causing vasodilation. The major endothelial derived relaxing factor was later discovered to be nitric oxide (NO). Endothelium-derived relaxing factor is produced and released by the endothelium that results in smooth muscle relaxation. It is released in response to a variety of chemical and physical stimuli. It causes the smooth muscle in the vessel wall to relax.People with diabetes usually have lower levels of Nitric Oxide than patients without diabetes. Diminished supply of Nitric Oxide can lead to vascular damage, such as endothelial dysfunction and vascular inflammation. Vascular damage can lead to decreased blood flow to the extremities, causing the diabetic patient to be more likely to develop Neuropathy, non-healing ulcers, and be at a greater risk for lower limb amputation.There is a natural phenomonon (collateral vessels) that bypasses distressed arteries.  The process begins when the system detects the distress, but if there is a stent implant the site isn't recognized as needing collaterals, but the system reacts to the simuli of a foreign substance in a varity of different responses.  An increase in the number of stents greatly increases the probability of unfavorable results notwithstanding drug eluding stents.If pain can be controlled with medication,  there is no need to risk interventional problems.

question: I have a question that has been bothering me.  I have 5 DES  in  the LAD  , 3 from a previous MI  and 2 from a blockage 1 year ago. I recently had a cath which came out good , no blockages.  My  new cardiologist says that ,   that  is too many stents for 1 artery and that my last blockage should have been a bypass rather than putting more  stents in that artery . I recently had a cath which came out good ,  no blockages.  I got a copy of the  CD  of the cathand I could see all the stents back to back with no gaps in between them ,  it measured a total of about  3 & 1/8  in. long.  I know there is alot of controversy lately about stents,  But I don,t understand why my cardiologist would think that 5 stents were the wrong thing to do.  Does anyone have an answer to that ?   Thanks.
title: TOO  MANY  STENTS???
